sp.speaker: Devon.
sp.l: You may ſee
How much we lay in Ballance with your goodneſs,
And had we more, it went; for we preſume
You cannot be religious and ſo vile.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: As to ſorſwear my ſelf, 'tis truth, great Sir,
The honour of your Bed hath been abus'd.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: But give me hearing, Sir,
'Twas far from my conſent, I was ſurpriz'd
By Villaines, and ſo raught.

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.l: Hear you that, Sirs?
Oh cunning texture to incloſe Adultery!
Mark but what ſubtile veil her ſin puts on,
Religion brings her to confeſſion firſt,
Then ſteps in Art to ſanctifie that luſt.
'Tis likely you could be ſurpriz'd.

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.p: I'le hear no more, our Guard, ſeize on thoſe Lords:

sp.speaker: Devon.
sp.l: We cannot periſh now too faſt, make ſpeed
To ſwift deſtruction; he breathes moſt accurſt
That lives ſo long to ſee his name dye firſt.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: Let him intreat, Sir,
That falls in ſaddeſt grief for this event,
Which ill begins the fortune of this Building, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: What if he ſhould cauſe me to ſwear too, Captain?
You know I am as far to ſeek in honeſty
As the worſt here can be; I ſhould be ſham'd too.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Why, fool, they ſwear by that we worſhip not,
So you may ſwear your heart out, and ne're hurt your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.p: That was well thought on, I had quite loſt my ſelf elſe.

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.l: You ſhall prevail in noble ſuits, my Lord,
But this does ſhame the ſpeaker.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I'le ſtep in now,
Though it ſhall be to no purpoſe; good my Lord
Think on your noble and moſt hopeful Iſſue
Lord Vortimer, the Prince.

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.l: A Baſtard, Sir,
I would his life were in my fury now.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: That injury ſtirs my Soul to ſpeak the truth
Of his conception; here I take the Book, my Lord:
By all the glorified rewards of Virtue
And prepared puniſhments for conſents in ſin,
A Quee s hard ſorrow ne're ſupplyed a Kingdom
With Iſſue more legitimate then Vortimer.

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.l: This takes not out the ſtain of preſent ſhame,
Continuance crowns deſert, ſhe ne're can go
For perfect honeſt that's not always ſo.
Beſhrew thy heart for urging this excuſe,
Th'haſt juſtified her ſomewhat.

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.l: Among ſo many women not one here
Dare ſwear a ſimple Chaſtity! here's an Age
To propagate vertue in: ſince I have begun,
I'le ſhame you all together, and ſo leave you.
My Lord of Kent!

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.l: Though I am your Gueſt to day,
And ſhould be leſs auſtere to you or yours,
In this caſe pardon me, I may not ſpare her.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.p: Then her own goodneſs friend her; ſhe comes my Lord.

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.l: The tender reputation of a Maid
Makes your honour, or elſe nothing can;
The oath you take is not for truth to man,
But to your own white ſoul, a mighty Task;
What dare you do in this?

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: My Lord, as much
As Chaſtity can put a woman to,
I ask no favour; and t'approve the purity
Of what my habit and my time profeſſeth;
As likewiſe to requite all courteous cenſure,
Here I take oath I am as free from man
As truth from falſhood, or ſanctity from flain.

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.l: Oh thou treaſure that raviſhes the poſſeſſor!
I know not where to ſpeed ſo well again,
I'le keep thee while I have thee; here's a Fountain
To ſpring forth Princes, and the ſeeds of Kingdoms.
Away with that infection of black honour, and thoſe her leprous pledges,
Here will we ſtore ſucceſſion with true peace,
And of pure Virgins grace the poor increaſe.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Ha ha, he's well provided now, here ſtruck my fortunes.
With what an impudent confidence ſhe ſwore honeſt,
Having th'advantage of the Oath! Precious Whore.
Methinks I ſhould not hear from fortune next
Under an Earldom now; ſhe cannot ſpend
A night ſo idly, but to make a Lord
With eaſe methinks and play: the Earl of Kent
Is calm and ſmooth, like a deep dangerous water;
He has ſome ſecret way, I know his bloud,
The grave's not greedier, nor Hells Lord more proud.
Something will hap; for this aſtoniſhing choice
Strikes pale the Kingdom, at which I rejoyce.

div.stage: Dumb ſhow. Enter Lupus, Germanus, Devonſhire, and Stafford, leading Vortimer, and Crown him: Vortiger comes to them in paſſion, they neglect him. Enter Roxena in fury expreſſing diſcontent, then they lead out Vortimer; Roxena gives two Villains gold to murther him, they ſwear performance and go with her: Vortiger offers to run on his ſword, Horſus prevents him, and perſwades him; the Lords bring in Vortimer dead; Vortiger mourns and ſubmits to them, they ſwear him, and Crown him. Then Enters Hengiſt with Saxons, Vortiger draws, threatens expulſion, and then ſends a Parley, which Hengiſt ſeems to grant by laying down his weapons, ſo all depart ſeverally.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Of Pagan bloud a Queen being choſe,
Roxena hight, the Britains roſe
For Vortimer, and crown'd him King,
But ſhe ſoon poyſon'd that ſweet Spring.
Then unto Rule they did reſtore
Vortiger, and him they ſwore
Againſt the Saxons; they (conſtrain'd)
Begg'd Peace, Treaty, and obtain'd;
And now in numbers equally
Upon the Plain neer Salisbury,
A peaceful meeting they decreen
Like men of love, no Weapon ſeen.
But Hengiſt, that ambitious Lord,
Full of guil, corrupts his word,
As the ſequel too well proves;
On that your eyes, on us your loves.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: If we let ſlip this opportuneful hour,
Take leave of fortune, certainty, or thought
Of ever fixing; we are looſe at root,
And the leaſt ſtorm may rend us from the boſom
Of this Lands hopes for ever. But, dear Saxons,
Faſten we now, and our unſhaken firmneſs
Will endure after Ages.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: Obſerve you not how Vortiger the King,
Baſe in ſubmiſſion, threatned our expulſion,
His arm held up againſt us? Is it not time
To make our beſt prevention? what ſhould check me?
He has perfected that great work in our Daughter,
And made her Queen, ſhe can aſcend no higher,
Therefore be quick, diſpatch; here, every man
Receive into the ſervice of his Vengeance
An inſtrument of Steel, which will unſeen
Lurk like a ſnake under the innocent ſhade
Of a ſpred Summer-leaf, there fly you on,
Take heart, the Commons love us, thoſe remov'd
That are the nerves, our greatneſs ſtands improv'd.

sp.speaker: Sax.
sp.p: Give us the word, my Lord, and we are perfect.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: That's true, the word, I loſe my ſelf. Nemp your Sexes.
It ſhall be that.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.p: But the King's mine, take heed you touch him not.

sp.speaker: Sax.
sp.l: We ſhall not be at leaſure, never fear it,
We ſhall have work enough of our own, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.p: Calm looks but ſtormy ſouls poſſeſs you all.

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.p: We ſee you keep your words in all points firm.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: No longer may we beaſt of ſo much breath
As goes to a words making, then of care
In the preſerving of it, when 'tis made.

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.l: Y'are in a vertuous way, my Lord of Kent,
And ſince both ſides are met like Sons of peace,
All other arms laid by in ſigns of favour
If our conditions be embrac'd.

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.p: We'le uſe no other but theſe only here.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: Follow it to the heart, my truſty Saxons,
It is your liberty, your wealth and honour. Soft, you are mine, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.l: Take me not baſely, when all ſence & ſtrength
Lies bound up in amazement at this treachery.
What Devil hath breath'd this everlaſting part
Of falſhood into thee?

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: Let it ſuffice,
I have you, and will hold you Priſoner,
As faſt as death holds your beſt props in ſilence:
We know the hard conditions of our peace,
Slavery or diminution, which we hate
With a joynt loathing: may all periſh thus
That ſeek to ſubjugate or leſſen us.

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.l: Oh the ſtrange nooks of guil or ſubtilty,
When man ſo cunningly lyes hid from man!
Who could expect ſuch treaſon from thy breaſt,
Such thunder from thy voice? or takeſt thou pride
To imitate the fair uncertainty
Of a bright day, that teemes a ſudden ſtorm,
When the world leaſt expects one? but of all
I'le ne're truſt fair skie in a man again,
There's the deceitful weather; will you heap
More guilt upon you, by detaining me,
Like a Cup taken after a ſore ſurfeit
Even in contempt of health and heaven together?
What ſeek you?

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: Ranſom for your Liberty
As I ſhall like of, or you ne're obtain it.

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.l: Here's a moſt headlong dangerous ambition,
Sow you the ſeeds of your aſpiring hopes
In bloud and treaſon, and muſt I pay for them?

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: Have not I rais'd you to this height of pride?
A work of my own merie, ſince you enforce it.

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.l: There's even the general thanks of all Aſpirers,
When they have a l a Kingdom can impart,
They write above it ſtill their own deſert.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.p: I have writ mine true, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.l: That's all their ſayings.
Have not I rais'd thy daughter to a Queen?

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: You have the harmony of your pleaſure for it,
You Crown your own deſires, what's that to me?

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.p: And what will Crown yours, Sir?

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: Faith things of reaſon,
I demand Kent.

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.p: Why y'nave the Earldom of it.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: The Kingdom of't I mean, without controul,
In full poſſeſſion.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: It ſeems y'are not acquainted with my bloud
To call this ſtrange.

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.l: Never was King of Kent
But who was general King.

sp.speaker: Heng▪
sp.l: I'le be the firſt then,
Every thing has beginning.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: Not if you hope for liberty, my Lord.
So dear a happineſs would not be wrong'd with ſlighting.

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.p: Very well, take it, I reſign it.

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.p: Is your great thirſt yet ſatisfied?

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: Faith, my Lord,
There's yet behind a pair of teeming Siſters,
Norfolk and Suffolk, and I have done with you.

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.l: Y'have got a dangerous thirſt of late, my Lord,
How e're you came by it.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: It behoves me then
For my blouds health to ſeek all means to quench it.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.p: There will nothing be abated, I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.l: You have me at advantage, he whom fate
Does captivate muſt yield to all; take them.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: And you your liberty and peace, my Lord,
With our beſt love and wiſhes. Here's an hour
Begins us Saxons in wealth, fame, and power.

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.l: Are theſe the nobleſt fruits and faireſt requitals
From works of our own raiſing?
Methinks the murther of Conſtantius
Speaks to me in the voice of it, and the wrongs
Of our late Queen, ſlipp'd both into one Organ.
Ambition, hell, my own undoing, luſt,
And all the brood of Plagues conſpire againſt me.
I have not a friend left me.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: My Lord, he dyes
That ſays it but your ſelf, were't that Thief-King
That has ſo boldly ſtoln his honours from you,
A treaſon rhat wrings tears from honeſt Man-hood.

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.l: So rich am I now in thy love and pity
I feel no loſs at all; but we muſt part,
My Queen and I to Cambria.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: My Lord, and I not nam'd,
That have vow'd laſting ſervice to my lives extreameſt minute?

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.p: Is my ſick fate bleſt with ſo pure a friend!

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: My Lord, no ſpace of Earth, nor breadth of Sea
Shall divide me from you.

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.l: Oh faithful treaſure!
All my loſt happineſs is made up in thee.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I'le follow you through the world, to cuckold you,
That's my way now; every one has his Toy
While he lives here; ſome men delight in Building,
A trick of Babel, which will ne're be left;
Some in conſuming what was rais'd with toiling,
Hengiſt in getting honour, I in ſpoiling.

div.head: SCENA 1.
div.stage: Enter Symon and his Brethren, Aminadab his Clerk.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: IS not that Rebel Oliver, that Traytor to my year,
Prehended yet?

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: Not yet, ſo pleaſe your Worſhip.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: Not yet ſay'ſt thou? how durſt thou ſay, not yet,
And ſee me preſent? thou malapert, that art good for nothing
But to write and read. Is his Loom ſeiz'd upon?

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: Yes, if it like your Worſhip, and 16 yards of Fuſtian.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: Good, let a yard be ſav'd to mend me between the Legs,
The reſt cut in pieces and given to the poor,
'Tis Heretick Fuſtian, and ſhould be burnt indeed,
But being worn thred-bare the ſhame will be as great,
How think you Neighbours?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Greater methinks the longer it is wore,
Where being once burnt it can be burnt no more.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: True, wiſe and moſt ſenſeleſs. How now, Sirra,
What's he approaching here in duſty pumps?

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: A Footman, Sir, to the great King of Kent.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: The King of Kent? ſhake him by the hand for me,
Th'are welcome, Footman, loe, my Deputy ſhakes thee,
Come when my year is out, I'le doe't my ſelf.
If 'twere a Dog that came from the King of Kent,
I keep thoſe Officers would ſhake him, I trow.
And what's the News with thee, thou well ſtew'd Footman?

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.l: With a few Saxons,
Intends this night to make merry with you.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: Merry with me? I ſhouldbe ſorry elſe, fellow,
And take it in ill part, ſo tell Kents King.
Why was I choſen, but that great men ſhould make
Merry with me? there is a jeſt indeed;
Tell him, I lookt fort't, and me much he wrongs,
If he forget Sym that cutout his thongs.

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: I'le run with your Worſhips anſwer.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: Do I prithee;
That fellow will be roſted againſt ſupper,
He's half enough already, his Brows baſte him.
The King of Kent! the King of Kirſendome
Shall not be better welcome; for you muſt imagine now, Neighbours,
This is the time when Kent ſtands out of Kirſendome,
For he that's King here now was never kirſen'd;
This for your more Inſtruction I thought fit,
That when you are dead you may teach your Children wit.
C • erk!

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: I muſt turn you
From the Hall to the Kitchin to night. Give order that 12 Pigs be
Roſted yellow; 9 Geeſe, and ſome 3 Larks for piddling meat;
And twenty Woodcocks, I'le bid all my Neighbours;
Give charge the mutton come in all bloud-raw, that is Infidels meat,
The King of Kent is a Pagan, and muſt be ſerv'd ſo.
And let thoſe Officers that ſeldom, or never go to Church
Bring it in, 'twill be the better taken. Run, run, come you hither
Now, take all my Cuſhions down and thwack them ſoundly,
After my Feaſt of Millers; for their Buttocks
Have left a peck of flower in them, beat them carefully
Over a bolting hutch, there will be enough
For a Pan-pudding, as your Dame will handle it.
Then put freſh water into both the Bough-pots,
And burn a little Juniper in the Hall-Chimney,
Like a beaſt as I was, I piſt out the fire laſt night,
And never dreamt of the Kings coming. How now,
Returned ſo quickly?

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: Pleaſe your Worſhip here are
A certain Company of Players.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: Country Comedians, Interluders, Sir,
Deſire your Worſhips favour
And leave to enact in the Town-Hall.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: In the Town-Hall?
'Tis ten to one I never grant them that;
Call them before my Worſhip.
If my houſe will not ſerve their turn, I would fain ſee
The proudeſt he lend them a barn:
Now, Sirs, are you Comedians?

sp.speaker: 2 Cheat.
sp.l: We are Sir, Comedians, Tragedians,
Tragi-Comedians, Comi-Tragedians, Paſtoriſts,
Humoriſts, Clowniſts, Satyriſts; we have them Sir,
From the hug to the ſmile, from the ſmile to the laugh,
From the laugh to the handkerchief.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: Y'are very ſtrong in the wriſt methinks;
And muſt all theſe good parts be caſt away
Upon Pedlers, and Malt-men, ha?

sp.speaker: 1 Cheat.
sp.p: For want of better company, if it pleaſe your Worſhip.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: What think you of me my Maſters?
Hum; have you audacity enough
To play before ſo high a perſon as my ſelf? will not
My countenance daunt you? for if you play before me
I ſhall often look on you, I give you that warning before hand,
Take it not ill my Maſters, I ſhall laugh at you,
And truly when I am leaſt offended with you;
It is my humour, but be not you abaſh'd.

sp.speaker: 1 Cheat.
sp.l: Sir, we have plaid before a Lord e're now,
Though we be Country Actors.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: A Lord? ha, ha,
Thou'lt find it a harder thing to pleaſe a Mayor.

sp.speaker: 2 Cheat.
sp.p: We have a Play wherein we uſe a horſe.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: Fellows, you uſe no horſe-play in my houſe,
My rooms are rubb'd, keep it for Hackney-men.

sp.speaker: 1 Cheat.
sp.p: We'le not offer it to your Worſhip.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.p: Give me a Play without a Beaſt, I charge you.

sp.speaker: 2 Cheat.
sp.p: That's hard, without a Cuckold or a Drunkard?

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: Oh thoſe Beaſts are often the beſt men in a Pariſh,
And muſt not be kept out. But which is your merrieſt play?
That I would hearken after.

sp.speaker: 2 Cheat,
sp.l: Your Worſhip ſhall hear
Their names, and take your Choice.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.p: And that's plain dealing. Come begin, Sir.

sp.speaker: 2 Cheat.
sp.p: The Whirligig, the Whibble, the Carwidgen.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.p: Hey day, what names are theſe!

sp.speaker: 2 Cheat.
sp.l: New names of late.
The Wild gooſe Chaſe.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: Is that come up again?
That was a Play when I was Prentice firſt.

sp.speaker: 2 Cheat.
sp.l: I, but the Cheater has learn'd more tricks of late,
And gulls the Clown with new additions.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.p: Then is your Clown a Coxcomb, which is he?

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: Fye, fye, your Company
Muſt fall upon him and beat him, he's too fair y'faith
To make the people laugh▪

sp.speaker: 1 Cheat.
sp.p: Not as he may be dreſt, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: Faith dreſs him how you will, I'le give him that gift
He will never look half ſcurvily enough▪
Oh the Clowns that I have ſeen in my time!
The very peeping out of one of them would have made
A young heir laugh, though his Father lay a dying;
A man undone in Law the day before (the ſaddeſt caſe that can be)
Might for his 2d have burſt himſelf with laughing,
And ended all his miſeries. Here was a merry world, my Maſters!
Some talk of things of State, of puling ſtuff;
There's nothing in a Play to a Clown,
If he have the grace to hit on it, that's the thing indeed,
The King ſhews well, but he ſets off the King;
But not the King of Kent, I mean not ſo,
The King is one, I mean, I do not know.

sp.speaker: 2 Cheat.
sp.l: Your Worſhip ſpeaks with ſafety, like a rich man,
And for your finding fault, our hopes are greater,
Neither with him the Clown, nor me the Cheater.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: Away then, ſhift, Clown, to thy motley Crupper,
We'le ſee them firſt, the King ſhall after ſupper.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: I commend your Worſhips wiſdom in that, Mr. Mayor.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: Nay 'tis a point of Juſtice, if it be well examined,
Not to offer the King worſe then I'le ſee my ſelf;
For a Play may be dangerous, I have known
A Great man poyſoned in a Play.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.p: But to what purpoſe many times I know not.

sp.speaker: Felt.
sp.p: Methinks they ſhould deſtroy one another ſo.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: Oh no no, he that's poyſoned is always made privy to it,
That's one good order they have among them. What joyful throat
Is that, Aminadab? what is the meaning of this cry?

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: Fates I thank you for this victorious day,
Bonfires of peaſe-ſtraw burn, let the Bells ring.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: There's two in mending, and you know they cannot.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: 'Las the Tenor's broken, ring out the Treble,
I am overcloy'd with joy; welcome thou Rebel▪

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: Art thou yet ſo ſtout?
Wilt thou not ſtoop for grace? then get thee out.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: I was not born to ſtoop but to my Loom,
That ſeiz'd upon, my ſtooping days are done;
In plain terms, if thou haſt any thing to ſay to me,
Send me away quickly, this is no biding place,
I underſtand there are Players in thy houſe,
Diſpatch me, I charge thee, in the name of all the Brethren.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: Nay now proud Rebel, I will make thee ſtay,
And to thy greater torment ſee a Play.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Oh Devil, I conjure thee by Amſterdam.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: Our word is paſt,
Juſtice may wink a while, but ſee at laſt▪
The Play begins, hold, ſtop him, ſtop him.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Oh that prophane trumper! oh, oh.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.p: Set him down there I charge you Officers.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: I'le hide my ears and ſtop my eyes.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.p: Down with his golls I charge you.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: Oh tyranny, tyranny, revenge it tribulation!
For Rebels there are many deaths, but ſure the only way
To execute a Puritan is ſeeing of a Play.
Oh I ſhall ſwound!

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: Which if thou doſt, to ſpite thee,
A Players Boy ſhall bring thee Aqua-vitae.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Oh I'le not ſwound at all for't, though I dye.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.p: Peace, here's a Raſcal, lift and edifie.

sp.speaker: 1 Cheat.
sp.p: I ſay ſtill he's an Aſs that cannot live by his wits.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: What a bold Raſcal's this? he calls us all Aſſes at firſt daſh,
Sure none of us live by our wits, unleſs it be Oliver the Puritan.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: I ſcorn as much to live by my wits as the proudeſt of you all.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.p: Why then y'are an Aſs for company, ſo hold your prating.

sp.speaker: 2 Cheat.
sp.l: Fellow in arms, welcome,
The News, the News?

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: Fellow in arms, quoth he?
He may well call him fellow in arms.
I am ſure th'are both out at the Elbows.

sp.speaker: 2 Cheat.
sp.l: Be lively, my heart, be lively, the Booty is at hand,
He's but a fool of a Yeomans eldeſt Son,
He's ballanc'd on both ſides, Bully; he's going to buy houſhold-ſtuff
With one pocket, and to pay rent with the other.

sp.speaker: 1 Cheat.
sp.l: And if this be his laſt day, my Chuck,
He ſhall forfeit his Leaſe, quoth the one pocket,
And eat his meat in wooden Platters, quoth the other.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: Faith then he's not ſo wiſe as he ought to be, to let
Such Tatt • rdemallians get the upper hand of him.

sp.speaker: 2 Cheat.
sp.l: I, but ſmally to our comfort, with both his hands in
His pockets; how is it poſſible to pick a Lock, when the Key
Is on the inſide of the Door?

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: Oh neighbours here's the part now
That carries away the Play, if the Clown miſcarry,
Farewell my hopes for ever, the Play's ſpoil'd.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: They ſay there is a fooliſh kind of thing call'd a Cheater
Abroad, that will gull any Yeomans Son of his purſe,
And laugh in his face like an Iriſhman.
I would fain meet with ſome of theſe Creatures,
I am in as good ſtate to be gull'd now as ever I was in my life,
For I have two purſes at this time about me, and I would fain be
Acquainted with that Raſcal that would take one of them now.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: Faith thou may'ſt be acquainted with two or three
That will do their good wills I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: 1 Cheat.
sp.p: That way's too plain, too eaſie I am afraid.

sp.speaker: 2 Cheat.
sp.l: Come, Sir, your moſt familiar Cheats take beſt,
They ſhew like natural things and leaſt ſuſpected,
Give me a round ſhilling quickly.

sp.speaker: 1 Cheat.
sp.l: It will fetch
But one of his hands neither, if it take.

sp.speaker: 2 Cheat.
sp.l: Thou art too covetous, let's have one out firſt, prithee,
There's time enough to fetch out th'other after.
Thou lieſt, 'tis lawful currant money.

sp.speaker: 1 Cheat.
sp.p: I ſay 'tis Copper in ſome Countries.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Here is a fray towards,
But I will hold my hands, let who will part them.

sp.speaker: 2 Cheat.
sp.l: Copper? I defie thee, and now I ſhall diſprove thee,
Look you, here's an honeſt Yeomans ſon of the Country,
A man of Judgement.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Pray you be covered, Sir,
I have Eggs in my Cap, and cannot put it off.

sp.speaker: 2 Cheat.
sp.p: Will you be tryed by him?

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.p: They look rather as if they would be tryed next Seſſions.

sp.speaker: 1 Cheat.
sp.p: Pray give your judgement of this piece of Coin, Sir.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Nay if it be Coin you ſtrive about,
Let me ſee it, I love money.

sp.speaker: 2 Cheat.
sp.p: Let him do his worſt, Sir.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Y'had both need wear cut clothes, y'are ſo cholerick.

sp.speaker: 2 Cheat.
sp.p: Nay rub it and ſpare not, Sir.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Now by this ſilver, Gentlemen,
It is good money, would I had a hundred of them.

sp.speaker: 2 Cheat.
sp.l: We hope well, Sir; th'other pocket
And we are made men.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: Oh neighbours, I begin to be ſick of this fool,
To ſee him thus couzen'd, I would make his caſe my own.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Still would I meet with theſe things call'd Cheaters.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: A whoreſon Coxcomb, they have met with thee,
I can no longer endure him with patience.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Oh my rent, my whole years rent!

sp.speaker: Sym▪
sp.l: A murrain on you,
This makes us Landlords ſtay▪ ſo long for our money.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: A ſcurvey hobby-horſe,
That could not leave his money with me, having ſuch a Charge
About him; a pox on thee for an Aſs, thou play a Clown?
I wil commit thee for offering it; Officers, away with him.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: What means your Worſhip? why you'l ſpoil the Play, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: Before the King of Kent ſhall be thus ſerv'd,
I'le play the Clown my ſelf, away with him.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: With me? if it pleaſe your Worſhip, 'twas my part.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: But 'twas a fooliſh part as ever thou plaid'ſt in thy life,
I'le make thee ſmoak for it, I'le teach thee to underſtand
To play a Clown, thou ſhalt know, every man
Is not born to it, away with him quickly,
He'le have the other Pocket pickt elſe, I heard them ſay it
With my own ears; ſee he's come in another diſguiſe
To cheat thee again.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: Come on, Sir, let us ſee what your
sp.stage: He throws off his Gown, diſcovering his doublet with a ſatten forepart and a Canvas back
sp.l: Knaveſhip can do at me now,
You muſt not think you have a Clown in hand,
The fool I have committed too, for playing the part.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Fie, good Sir come away,
Will your Worſhip baſe your ſelf to play a Clown?

sp.speaker: 2 Cheat.
sp.l: I beſeech your Worſhip let us have our own Clown,
I know not how to go forwards elſe.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: Knave, play out thy part with me,
Or I'le lay thee by the heels all the days of thy life.
Why how now, my Maſters, who is that laugh'd at me?
Cannot a man of Worſhip play the Clown a little for his pleaſure
But he muſt be laugh'd at? do you know who I am?
Is the Kings Deputy of no better account among you?
Was I choſen to be laugh'd at? where's my Clerk?

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: Here, if it pleaſe your Worſhip.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: Take a Note of all thoſe
That laugh at me, that when I have done I may commit them.
Let me ſee who dare do it now. And now to you once again
Sir Cheater, look you, here are my purſe-ſtrings, I do defie thee.

sp.speaker: 2 Cheat.
sp.l: Good Sir, tempt me not, my part is ſo written
That I ſhould cheat your Worſhip if you were my Father.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.p: I ſhould have much joy to have ſuch a Raſcal to my Son.

sp.speaker: 2 Cheat.
sp.l: Therefore I beſeech your Worſhip pardon me, the part
Has more Knavery in it then when your Worſhip ſaw it at firſt,
I aſſure you you'l be deceiv'd in it, Sir, the new Additions
Will take any mans purſe in Kent or Kirſendome.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: If thou canſt take my purſe, I'le give it thee freely,
And do thy worſt, I charge thee; as thou'lt anſwer it.

sp.speaker: 2 Cheat.
sp.p: Say you ſo? then there's for you, and here is for me:

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: Oh bleſs me, Neighbours, I am in a Fogg,
sp.stage: Throws meal in his face, takes his purſe, & Exit.
sp.l: A Cheaters Fogg, I can ſee no body.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: Away, let him go,
He will have all your purſes, if he come back,
A pox on your new Additions, they ſpoil all the plays
That ever they come in, the old way had no ſuch roguery in it;
Calls you this a merry Comedy, when a mans eyes are put out in't?
Brother Honey-ſuckle.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: I make you Deputy to rule the Town till I can ſee again,
Which will be within theſe nine days at fartheſt.
Nothing grieves me now, but that I hear Oliver the Rebel
Laugh at me; a pox on your Puritan face, this will make you in
Love with Plays as long as you live,
We ſhall not keep you from them now.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: In ſincerity,
I was never better pleas'd at an exerciſe. Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: Neighbours, what colour was the duſt
The Raſcal threw in my face?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: 'Twas meal, if it pleaſe your Worſhip.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: Meal? I am glad of it,
I'le hang the Miller for ſelling it.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Nay ten to one
The Cheater never bought it, he ſtole it certainly.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: Why then I'le hang the Cheater for ſtealing it,
And the Miller for being out of the way when he did it.

sp.speaker: Felt:
sp.l: I but your Worſhip was in the fault your ſelf,
You bid him do his worſt.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: His worſt? that's true,
But the Raſcal hath done his beſt; for I know not how a Villain
Could put out a mans eyes better, and leave them in his head,
As he has done mine.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.p: How now Aminadab? I hear thee though I ſee thee not.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: You are ſure couzened, Sir, they are all profeſſed Cheaters,
They have ſtoln two ſilver ſpoons, and the Clown took his heels
With all celerity; they only take the name of Country-Comedians
To abuſe ſimple people with a printed play or two,
Which they bought at Canterbury for ſix pence,
And what is worſe, they ſpeak but
What they liſt of it, and fribble out the reſt.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: Here's no abuſe to the Common-wealth,
If a man could ſee to look into it,
But mark the Cunning of theſe cheating ſlaves,
Firſt they make Juſtice blind, then play the Knaves.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: Od's precious Brother, the King of Kent is newly alighted▪

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: The King of Kent? where is he,
That I ſhould live to this day,
And yet not live to ſee to bid him welcome?

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.p: Where is Symonides, our friendly Hoſt?

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.p: Ah blind as one that had been fox'd a ſevenight▪

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: Faith practiſing a Clowns part for your Grace
I have practis'd both my eyes out.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: A man is never too old to learn, your Grace will ſay ſo,
When you hear the jeſt of it; the truth is, my Lord, I meant
To have been merry, and now it is my luck to weep
Water and Oatmeal; I ſhall ſee again at Supper,
I make no doubt of it.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.p: This is ſtrange to me, Sirs.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: With ſwifteſt ſpeed, if ever you'l behold
The Queen your Daughter alive again.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: They are beſieged, Aurelius,
Ambroſe, and his Brother Uther,
With numbers infinite of Britiſh Forces,
Beſet their Caſtle, and they cannot ſcape
Without your ſpeedy ſuccour.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.p: For her ſafety I'le forget food and reſt: away.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.p: I hope your Worſhip will hear the jeſt e're you go.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: I'le follow you to Wales with a Dog and a Bell
But I will tell it you.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: 'Tis ſign of war when great men diſagree;
Look to the Rebel well, till I can ſee,
And when my ſight is recover'd, I will have
His eyes pull'd out for a fortnight.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: My eyes? hang thee,
A deadly ſin or two ſhall pluck them out firſt,
That is my reſolution. Ha, ha, ha.

div.head: ACT. 5. SCENA 2.
div.stage: Enter Aurelius and Uther with Soldiers, (Vortiger and Horſus above.)

sp.speaker: Uther.
sp.p: MY Lord, the Caſtle is ſo fortified.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Let wild-fire ruine it,
That his deſtruction may appear to him
In the figure of Heavens wrath at the laſt day,
That Murtherer of our Brother. Hence away,
I'le ſend my heart no peace till it be conſum'd.

sp.speaker: Uth.
sp.p: There he appears again, behold, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Oh that the zealous fire on my Souls Altar,
To the high Birth of Virtue conſecrated,
Would fit me with a lightning now to blaſt him,
Even as I look upon him.

sp.speaker: Uth.
sp.l: Good my Lord,
Your anger is too noble and too precious
To waſte it ſelf on guilt ſo foul as his;
Let ruine work her will.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: All, all, my Lord, 'tis folly to make doubt of it,
You queſtion things that horror long ago
Reſolv'd us on.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Do what you will, Sir, queſtion them again,
I'le tell them to you.

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.l: Not ſo, Sir,
I will not have them told again▪

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.l: That's an ill word put in, when thy heart knows
There is no reſt at all, but torment making.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: True, my heart finds it; that ſits weeping bloud now
For poor Roxena's ſafety. You'l confeſs, my Lord,
My love to you has brought me to this danger?
I could have liv'd like Hengiſt, King of Kent,
London, York, Lincoln, and Wincheſter,
Under the power of my Command, the portion
Of my moſt juſt deſert, enjoyed now
By pettier, Deſervers.

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.l: Say you ſo, Sir,
And you'l confeſs? ſince you began Confeſſion
(A thing I ſhould have died e're I had thought on)
Y'have mari'd the faſhion of your affection utterly,
In your own wicked counſel, there you paid me,
You were bound in conſcience to love me after,
You were bound to't, as men in honeſty,
That vitiate Virgins, to give Dowries to them;
My faith was pure before to a faithful woman.

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.l: Why I'le be judg'd by theſe
That knit death in their Brows, and hold me now
Not worth the acception of a flattery,
Moſt of whoſe faces ſmil'd when I ſmil'd once; my Lords:

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.l: Seeds of ſcorn, I mind you not,
I ſpeak to them alone whoſe force makes yours a power,
Which elſe were none. Shew me the main food of your hate,
Which cannot be the Murther of Conſtantius
That crawls in your Revenges; for your loves
Were violent long ſince that.

sp.speaker: 1 Lo.
sp.l: And had been ſtill,
If from that Pagan wound th'hadſt kept thee free,
But when thou fledd'ſt from Heaven, we fled from thee.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Mine? 'twas the Counſel
Of your own luſt and bloud, your appetite knows it.

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.l: May thunder ſtrike me from theſe walls, my Lords,
And leave me many Leagues off from your eyes,
If this be not the man, whoſe Stygian Soul
Breath'd forth that counſel to me, and ſole Plotter
Of all thoſe falſe injurious diſgraces
That have abus'd the vertuous patience
Of our Religious Queen.

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.l: Upon whoſe life, I ſwear, there ſticks no ſtain
But what's moſt wrongful, and where now ſhe thinks
A rape dwe • ls on her honour, only I
Her Raviſher was, and his the Policy.

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.l: Now you know the truth,
Will his death ſerve your fury?

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.p: It ſhall, ſpeak but the word, it ſhall be yielded up.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Believe him not, he cannot do it.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: 'Tis but a falſe and baſe Inſinuation
For his own life, and like his late ſubmiſſion.

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.l: Oh ſting to honour, alive or dead thou goeſt
For that words rudeneſs only.

sp.speaker: 1 Lo.
sp.l: See, ſin needs
No other deſtruction then it breeds in its own boſom.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: What, has thy vile rage ſtamp'd a wound upon me?
I' • e ſend one to thy ſoul ſhall never heal for't.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: It ſhall be thy maſter-torment
Both for the pain and the everlaſtingneſs.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Doſt laugh? take leave of it, all eternity
Shall never ſee thee do ſo much again:
Know th'art a Cuckold.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: You change too ſoon, Sir.
Roxena, whom th'haſt rais'd to thy own ruine,
She was my Whore in Germany.

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.p: Burſt me open the violence of whirl-winds:

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Hear me out firſt,
For her embrace, which my fleſh yet ſits warm in,
I was thy friend and follower.

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.l: Deafen me
Thou moſt imperious noiſe that ſtarts the world!

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: And to ſerve both our luſts I practis'd with thee
Againſt thy vertuous Queen.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Whoſe faithful ſweetneſs, too precious for thy bloud,
I made thee change for loves Hypocriſie.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Only to make my way to pleaſure fearleſs, free & fluent.

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.p: Hells Trump is in that throat.

div.stage: They ſtab each other. Rox. enters in fear.

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.p: I'le damme it up with death firſt.

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: Oh for ſuccour!
Who's neer me? help me, ſave me, the flame follows me,
'Tis in the figure of young Vortimer, the Prince,
Whoſe life I took by poyſon.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Hold out breath and I ſhall find thee quickly.

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.p: I'le tug thy ſoul out here.

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: Oh hear me,
Oh help me, my Love, my Lord, 'tis here,
Horſus look up, if not to ſuccour me,
To ſee me yet conſum'd; oh what is love
When life is not regarded?

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.p: What ſtrength's left I'le fix upon thy throat.

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: No way to ſcape? is this the end of glory?
Doubly beſet with enemies wrath and fire:
It comes nearer, rivers and fountains fall,
It ſucks away my breath, I cannot give
A curſe to ſin, and hear't out while I live. Help, help.

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.l: Burn, burn, now I can t • nd thee,
Take time with her in torment, call her life
A far off to thee, dry up her ſtrumpet-bloud,
And hard y parch the skin, let one heat ſtrangle her,
Another fetch her to her ſenſe again,
And the worſt pain be only her reviving,
Follow her eternally; oh myſtical Harlot,
Thou haſt thy full due, whom luſt crown'd Queen before
Flames crown her now a moſt triumphant Whore.
And that end crowns them all.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Our peace is full,
In you Uſurpers fall, nor have I known
A Judgement meet more fearfully.
Here, take this Ring, deliver the good Queen,
And thoſe grave pledges of her murthered honour,
(Her worthy Father, and her noble Uncle.)
How now ▪ the meaning of theſe ſounds?

sp.speaker: Heng▪
sp.l: The Conſumer has been here, ſhe's gone, ſhe's loſt,
In glowing Cinders now lye all my joys,
The headlong Fortune of my raſh Captivity
Strikes not ſo deep a wound into my hopes
As thy dear loſs.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Part of my wiſhes,
What fortunate power has prevented me,
And e're my love came, brought them victory?

sp.speaker: 1 Lo.
sp.p: My wonder ſticks in Hengiſt King of Kent.

sp.speaker: Devon.
sp.l: My Lord, to make that plain which now I ſee
Fix'd in aſtoniſhment; the only name
Of your Return and Being brought ſuch gladneſs
To this diſtracted Kingdom, that, to expreſs
A thankfulneſs to Heaven, it grew great
In charitable Actions, from which goodneſs
We taſte our liberty, who liv'd engag'd
Upon the Innocence of womans honour,
(A kindneſs that even threatned to undo us)
And having newly but enjoy'd the benefit
And fruits of our enlargement, 'twas our happineſs
To intercept this Monſter of Ambition,
Bred in theſe times of Uſurpation,
The ranckneſs of whoſe Inſolence and Treaſon
Grew to ſuch height, 'twas arm'd to bid you Battle.
Whom, as our fames Redemption, on our knees
We preſent Captive.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Had it needed reaſon
You richly came provided, I underſtood
Not your deſerts till now; my honoured Lords,
Is this that German Saxon, whoſe leaſt thirſt
Could not be ſatisfied under a Province?

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: Had but my fate directed this bold arm
To thy life, the whole Kingdome had been mine,
That was my hopes great aim; I have a thirſt
Could never have been full quench'd under all,
The whole muſt doe't or nothing.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: A ſtrange draught!
And what a little ground ſhall death now teach you
To be content withal?

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: Why let it then,
For none elſe can, y'have nam'd the only way
To limit my Ambition, a full cure
For all my fading hopes and ſickly fears;
Nor ſhall it be leſs we come to me now
Then a freſh acquiſition would have been
Unto my new built Kingdoms; Life to me,
('Leſs it be glorious) is a miſery.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: That pleaſure we will do you; Lead him out,
And when we have inflicted •• r juſt doom
On his uſurping head, it will become
Our pious care to ſee this Realm ſecur'd
From the Convulſions it hath long endur'd.
